1283040974965559299.text: "...in an age like ours, which demands bold thinking and action, a systemic problem like colonialism calls for a systemic solution like statehood. A comprehensive decolonization of Puerto Rico is long overdue."

1283040874562191362.text: "...the ultimate solution to inequality is equality itself, which can only be conferred by statehood. Everything else, like tinkering with reimbursement formulas, is piecemeal policymaking..."

1283040763903975429.text: "Like Native Americans and African-Americans, women and LGBTQ people, Puerto Ricans should be seen as part of the same overarching struggle for equality — in a nation whose greatest vice is the perennial failure to practice the virtue it preaches."

1283040710409822210.text: "That being said, the process of self-determination matters more than particular proposals: Congress should codify the will of the people on the island, whatever it may be."

1283040610354700288.text: "If commonwealth status is colonialism in disguise and if independence commands support only at the margins, then the only viable option that remains is statehood."

1283040531371692032.text: "Puerto Ricans are and have long been American citizens. Instead of depriving them of citizenship entirely, make Puerto Ricans equal under the law."

1283040443870187531.text: "How can the United States claim to be fully democratic when it openly denies equal representation to 3 million people who are citizens according to its own laws, and when it subverts the popularly elected government of Puerto Rico in favor of a Financial Control Board..."

1283040364094459905.text: "As Americans, we must speak out against the disenfranchisement of our fellow citizens in Puerto Rico, for it represents a deep rot at the very core of American democracy, not to mention a manifestation of the very systemic racism against which millions have stood in protest."

1283040185219985409.text: "At a time when American discourse has centered around historical racism, the colonial status of Puerto Rico should be seen through the same lens: as a legacy handed down to us by the judicial architects of Jim Crow."

1283040096531480583.text: "It is little-known that the Supreme Court justices who gave us Plessy vs. Ferguson and its progeny “separate but equal” — a pillar of Jim Crow — are the same robed racists who, at the turn of the 20th century, relegated Puerto Rico to the status of a colony..."

1283039963848888322.text: "Exercising dominion over Puerto Rico, as the U.S. has done for more than a century — without granting Puerto Ricans the full franchise in federal elections — is the essence of colonialism."

1143170507757559809.text: The collapse of the medallion market, should be remembered as one of the greatest government scandals in the history of NYC.
